title: Drought no dampener as Elders farmland sales top $1b again
text:
“We continue to see strong interest in farmland assets of scale and are presently assisting numerous large private operators, corporate investors and fund managers to identify and acquire quality holdings," said Tom Russo, general manager of real estate at Elders Limited.

“Whilst drought-impacted areas have seen a substantial reduction in listings and transaction volumes, strong ongoing demand for farmland has maintained upward pressure on values.

"Assets of quality and scale continue to attract investment capital given the strong outlook for soft commodities and the attractive portfolio diversification provided by exposure to farmland," Mr Russo said.

Notable properties that Elders agents were involved in over the 12 months to September 30 include the historic Mount Fyans holding in Victoria's Western District, which sold for $37 million in December to Ian and Camilla Shippen, the February sale of media mogul Kerry Stokes and veteran cattleman Peter Murray's Cygnet Park Farms aggregation on Kangaroo Island for about $25 million to agricultural fund manager Growth Farms and the sale of Gerry’s Harvey’s Coomboona dairy.

Elders sold Mount Fyans in December for $37 million.

Speaking at an investor conference in September, Elders chief executive Mark Allison said supply of farmland would continue to be subdued in line with livestock prices, but gains were expected from its water-broking activities.

Figures provided to The Australian Financial Review show water trading was a stand-out area for Elders over the past financial year, with $111 million worth of water rights sold, up 40 per cent on the previous year.

Elders' combined franchise and company-owned operations sold about $4.5 billion of real estate in the 2019 financial year, down from the $4.71 billion reported in 2018.

Advertisement

Mr Russo said the slight reduction was due to its weaker performing franchise network of real estate offices, which account for only a small part of group revenue.

Alongside $1.12 billion of farmland sales, Elders' company-owned residential agencies sold $726 million of residential real estate, up from $710 million the previous year, with properties under management increasing by more than 1000 to about 9300.

Mr Russo said in comparison, McGrath Estate Agents cited decade-low residential property listing levels in August when it reported annual revenue decline of 17 per cent.

Tom Russo says Elders is doing a lot better than McGrath.

Elders, whose other main businesses include selling farm products, agency services (livestock, wool and grain) and financial services, will report full-year results on November 11.

The company has forecast underlying earnings before interest and tax of between $72 and $75 million. EBIT for the 2018 financial year was $74.6 million.
description: Farmland sales rose 8 per cent to $1.12 billion in the year to September 30, while residential sales also increased.
